Award.AwardTitle: CCSS: An Architecture for Joint Integration of Inter and Intrasession Network Coding in Lossy Wireless Multihop Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to improve the capacity and energy efficiency of different lossy wireless networks with different processing capabilities. The proposed approach is to synergistically and systematically combine two types of coding in wireless networks: intra and intersession network coding. The first one resolves bottlenecks by coding the packets of different flows, while the second one provides robustness to the link failures by coding the packets of the same flow together.

Intellectual merit: The research has three major thrusts. The first thrust investigates the characterization and the fundamental limits of the proposed approach in lossy wireless networks under different settings. The settings include the unicast and multicast cases, the use of coding over multihops, and the use of coding with other traffic engineering techniques. The second thrust involves the design of distributed network protocols based on the insights drawn from the characterization. The designed protocols are ensured to be compatible with the current Internet and computer network standards. The final thrust deals with deploying the proposed protocols in different application settings and developing a simulator that captures the actual behavior of the protocols in different wireless networking scenarios.

Broader impacts: This research has the potential to increase the role of coding in wireless networks, as it will tackle the fundamental characterization of coding in these networks. Research results will be integrated into the community mesh network of the city of Philadelphia. The protocols developed will also impact the broader community through programs at Temple University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Two common types of network coding have been utilized for wireless networks. Intrasession network coding provides redundancy to resolve the lossy behavior of the diverse wireless links. Intersession network coding, on the the other hand, resolves the bottlenecks in wireless networks to maximize the throughput and capacity. This project studied the joint design of both intra and intersession network coding in lossy wireless networks. 

 

The general form of the problem is very hard to solve. Therefore, the exploration started with investigating two-hop relay networks. For this small network, random network coding with interference cancellation was utilized to achieve the capacity as well as efficient solutions. Based on this solution for two-hop relay networks, bigger networks are decomposed into a set of small two-hop relay networks and superposition approaches were applied to develop both centralized and distributed algorithms. 

 

After that, many extensions of the problem were studied. One extension was when the packets have deadline constraints. The problem was shown to be NP-hard and several approximations were developed. Another extension was to consider the correlations among the wireless links as it could be arbitrary. A distributed solution based on combining the coded-feedback approach and the queue length information was developed. The developed distributed algorithm was shown to achieve the optimal solution without the need to explicitly know the correlations among the links. This algorithm was extended to the multicast case and simulation results showed that the new approach achieved 2 to 3-fold improvement in throughput over the-state-of-the-art methods.

 

The joint intra and intersession coding was also extended to the multi-rate media streaming case, in which the video content is composed of multiple layers and all of the lower level layers are necessary to decode a given layer. Coding was performed here within the layer or among the layers. Triangular joint intra and interlayer network coding was studied and several distributed and centralized algorithms were developed under different settings. The results showed that triangular network coding provided improvement over the non-coded solution and the intralayer coding techniques.

 

The results of this project advanced the knowledge in the area of jointly applying intra and intersession network coding. The results also provided more practical approaches to apply the joint design in wireless networks.
